Subject. India Office letter Mated 21st March 1933, with enclosures. Activities Bushire demi-official letter of No.394-S of 19th April 1933 Mr. to the India Office. Gerhardt Breisnick. Foreign Office Printed - letter ilo.E. 1999/11/91 of 1 1 * 25th April 1933, with enclosure. U i4 y it * h V , ‘S •Copy INDIA OFFICE, WHITEHALL, S.W.l. 21st March 1933, I enclose copy of a letter dated Sth March from Rendel of the Foreign Office about the activities of a young German naned Breisnich, which is, I think, self- explanatory. *ou will see that the Foreign Office have sent a copy of the correspondence to the Embassy at Bagdad for observations, and we should be grateful for any observations which you may wish to offer upon it. I am sending a copy of this letter to Metcalfe. *our sincerely, (Sd.) J. C. Walton. The Hon*ble Lt.Col.T.C.W.Fowle,C.B.E., The Residency, Bushire.P.2.13T8/7.3. FOREIGN OFFICE,S.W.l. 9th March 1933. (K 1170/11/91). My dear Gilbert, I enclose a copy of a letter we have received from Colonel Burchall of Imperial Airways regarding the activities of a young German named Breisnick, who has been visiting the Arabian coast of the Persian Gulf. 2 # We are sending a copy of Burchall s letter to the Embassy at Bagdad for observations, and you may per haps like to consult the Political Resident also. lours,etc., (Sd.j GEORGE RENDEL. &kkkkCOPY. (E 1170/11/91;. H3/PS/2027. confidential. M- IMPERIAL AIRWAYS,LTD., AIRWAYS TERMINUS, VICTORIA STATION, LONDON S.W.l. 28th February, 1933. Dear Mr. Rendel, I do not know whether I ought to bring these facts to your notice, but it is very simple to tear up the letter if the point is of no interest. Our Manager in Cairo, who recently went along the Arabian Coast of the Persian Gulf met a number of people, who told him about a young German v/ho was apparently working his passage from point to point and making at the same time a pretty good survey of the resources of the west side of the Gulf. His name was Gerhardt Breisnick. He is believed to be from Berlin University, aged about 20, and said he was studying psychology and character building. He has been to Baghdad visiting UR and had come from Basrah to Bahrain in a dhow. He is said to have asked a number of questions re garding our operations. Yours, etc.» ( d.) H. BURCHALL• Copy to Mr. Bertram, Air Ministry. G. Rendel, Esq., Foreign Office, S.W.l.Confidential D.O.No.394-S of 1933. The Residency, Bushire, the 19th April,1933 Will you kindly refer to your demi-official letter dated the 21st March 1933 about a young German named Breisnick. with another German student named F. Rosenthal on the 28th December 1932. It was understood that they had come down the Tigris in a canoe. They proposed to go to India by way of Bahrain and Muscat. Rosenthal had apparently been refused a visa for India by the British Consul at Basrah as he could not prove that he had any means, he was, therefore, refused a visa at Kuwait also. Breisnick’s passport hore a visa for India given by the British Consul in Berlin, so he was given a visa to Bahrain. 3. I saw Breisnick when he passed through Bahrain, where Dr. Dame of the American Mission allowed him to use a bed in the European room of their Hospital, neither the Missionaries nor I found any reason to think that he was other than a student of the ’hiker* type, keen to see the world and possibly collecting material for a thesis. 4. He proposed to go on to India by dhow by way of the Trucial Coast and Muscat, but readily accepted my land Dr. Dame’s) advice to make this part of his journey by steamer. 5. Dr. Dame has since had a line from him from l I think) Lahore* 6. I am sending a copy of this letter to Metcalfe. 2. Breisnick arrived at Kuwait by sailing boat in company Yours sincerely lSd.) G. LOCH J.C.Walt on,Esq.,C.B.,M.C., THE INDIA OFFICE, London© P*Z. 2396/33* SBNT VO Ko.E*1999A1/91 The Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affaire preeente hie complimente to The Under-Secretary of 'tate for India, and, by direction of the Secretary of State, tranRiaits herewith copy of the under-mentioned paper* Foreign Office, April 25th, 1933* Foreign Office letter S 1170/11/91 of March 9th (Mr* Rendel to Mr. ^aithwaite.) Reference to previous correspondence; Description of Shclosure Name and Date Subj ect ii*i:.Reprarentative Activitiee of Mr. Gerhardt Brei snick. Bag?lad No. 213 April 4.P*Z*2396/33 /-V Ho. 213. British ^mbarsy, (230/4/33) Bajdsd* 4th April, 1933. Sir, With reference to your despatch No# 147 (£ 1170A1/^1) of the 9th March, I have the honour to inform you that Gerhardt Breisnick arrived in ’Iraq from Syria on the 15th November, 1932, in company with a German Jew merchant named Frans Rerenthal# Both remained for several days in Bagdad and then, after visiting Kerbela and Ur, arrived in Basra on the 13th December, 1932* There they remained until the 21st December when they left for Abadan* Roeenthal returned to ’Iraq and left for Persia on the 27th January, 1933* 2* I regret that I have no information concerning Breisnick’s activities in the Peraian Gulf* I have the honour, etc*, (Sgd.) (e #oeo/n/®i) BRITISH WEA‘53Y, n R T .n». 8th June, D^ar Oaorgo, ’frith reference to /orel^n Of loe deapatoh Ho. 440 (K 2630/11/91) of the 25th Way, regarding a 0* r*»n atudent who was travelling to Tndta via the Persian Gulf, you »nay care to have the fallowing remark* by Foley, the Passport Control Officer here. ^Aa the Residency at Buahire states definitely that thie aan’a passport bears a British visa granted by me, I have had another search made, and find t!\at his noma has been consistently misspelt In all the documents of the file. ’♦It is Cterhard Augustus Frederik Brlesenlck (not Breianick). f, He was born on the 9/6/12 «n*i lived at Berlin W*57 Zletenstrss&e 6b« ”He was recommended to us by the Deutsche araphologlsche ?tudiengesellschaft as a student of Graphology. The Society was Interested in his visit to India «a it was desired he should study graphological institutions f*nd conditions there. 'I examined Briesenlck and authorised a visa. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘19/2 Gerhard Augustus Frederick Briesewick - A German Student’

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover and terminates at the back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-11; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: This file concerns the activities of a German named Gerhard Augusta Frederick Briesenick believed to be a student of Berlin University, travelling to India via the Arabian coast of the Persian Gulf. The file contains correspondence between Lieutenant-Colonel Percy Gordon Loch, Political Agent at Bahrain, and Lieutenant-Colonel Trenchard Craven Fowle, Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; and John Charles Walton of the India Office, London.
